DOC.TEXT: Stock prices dropped sharply today in selling blamed on spreading worries about the real-estate outlook. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 14.08 on Friday, tumbled 47.78 to 2,691.77 by 3 p.m. today on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 311 up, 1,275 down and 385 unchanged. Brokers said traders remained uneasy about the outlook for real-estate finance and regional bank stocks after the Bank of New England on Friday announced projected increases in its loan-loss reserve and non-performing assets. In the past couple of weeks, Wall Street has been devoting increased concern to the soft real estate market in many parts of the country and the problems real-estate debt might pose should prices of properties lag for an extended period. Bank of New England shares led the active list, down 1\ at 7} on the heels of a 3]-point drop Friday. Among other mortgage and regional banking issues, Citytrust Bancorp fell 1} to 15]; Federal National Mortgage 3 to 30}, and Federal Home Loan Mortgage 4\ to 63{. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included International Business Machines, down 1{ at 93{; American Express, down 1| at 31|; USX, down 1\ at 33|, and McDonald's, down { at 33}. Otherwise, analysts said traders began dumping stocks on fears that a yearend rally they had been hoping for might not materialize. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 3.93 to 189.52. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 5.21 at 370.29. Volume on the Big Board came to 152.12 million shares with an hour to go.
